Introduction There are many works for protein modeling regarding proteins as a 1-d sequences. From this perspective, proteins resembles natural languages - amino acides are the language tokens. One huge advantage of such approach is that it enables the easy utilization of the rich existing works for natural language modeling where great success has been achieved in recent years However, proteins have four levels of structure that is essential for their function. In this blog, I will introduce recent works on modeling protein structures.
GVP One paper “Learning from protein structure with geometric vector perceptrons.” proposes a novel Geometric Vector Perceptrons (GVP) combining with Graph Neural Networks (GNN) to model protein structure. More specifically, this paper focuses on modeling the first and second structures of proteins - amino sequence and the backbone of polypeptides. There are two major contributions of this paper. The first is the feature engineering.
Feature Engineering For the $i$-th residue, there are four features extracted:
Feature engineering for residues. Source:[1]
In addition, it constructs a graph $\mathcal{G}=(\mathcal{V}, \mathcal{E})$ from the polypeptides where the nodes of the graph are residues and the edges are formed as follows: each residue connects to $k$ neigbors that are closest to it in terms of the minimum euclidean distances. The features extracted for the edge from node $v_i$ to $v_j$ are the follows:
Feature engineering for edges. Source:[1]
Essentially, the first and second features encode the physical distance while the third one encode the sequential distance. Both node (residue) and edge feautures can be classified into two categories: scalar and vector. The scalar ones are traditional features while vector ones are designed to fully capture complex geometry.
With the constructed graph, an graph neural network is proposed to propogate node and edge features. In the propogation steps, a novel feature transforming layer called GVP is proposed, which is the second major contribution.
GVP: Geometric Vector Perceptrons The GVP is designed to directly operate on scalar and vector features. The algorithm and its illustration is shown below.
The GVP algorithm. Source:[1]
The illustration of GVP. Source:[1]
The most important property of GVP is that vector and scalar outputs of the GVP are equivariant and invariant, respectively. Mathematically: if $\bar{s}, \bar{V} = \text{GVP}(s, V)$, then $\bar{s}, R(\bar{V}) = \text{GVP} (s, R(V))$, where $R(\cdot)$ indicates an arbitrary composition of rotations and reflections. The original paper provides detailed proof for this property. In essence, it is achieved through the $L_2$ norm invariance with unitary matrix multiplication.
References [1]Jing, et al. “Learning from protein structure with geometric vector perceptrons.” ICLR 2021

content:
Amino acids and proteins The basic molecule units of proteins are amino acids. A amino acid consists of three major groups: amino ($-\text{NH}_3^+)$, carboxylic acid ($-\text{CO}_2{\text H}$) and a side chain ($\text{R}$). The carbon that attaches amino group is called alpha carbon. The following figure illustrates the simple structure of an amino acid.
The general structure of amino acid that consists of three groups: amino, carboxylic acid and side chain
There are 22 types of amino acides. It is the side chain that differentiates them. Two amino acids can form a peptide bond: the carboxylic acid group of one reacts to the amino group of the other, which yields the newly formed peptide bond and a molecule of water. The formation procedure is shown below.
The formation of peptide bond
The structure of peptide bond can be discribed with Dihedral angles that are illustrated in the following figure.
The Dihedral angles of peptide bond
In a similar way, this peptide bond can react with other amino acids and form a chain which is named as polypeptide. Each “amino acid” in a polypeptide is called residue. The backbone of a polypeptide are the chain of nitrogen - alpha carbon - carbon. The following figure shows a backbone structure of a peptide bond.
The backbone of a peptide
For proteins, there are four levels of struture:
1-d sequence of amino acides decided by peptide bonds. (Secondery structure) Folding of amino acides determined by backbone interactions (amino acides fold upon themselves). There are two motifs: $\alpha$ helix $\beta$ sheet (Tertiary structure) highly-order folding within a polypeptide depending on distant interactions. (Quaternary structure) the bonding of multiple polypeptides. References [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amino_acid
[2] https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/biomolecules
